pros: NTT Data is a global IT services provider that offers a wide range of services, including consulting, application development and management, data analytics, infrastructure management, and more. Working for NTT Data has several potential benefits, including: Global Reach: NTT Data operates in over 50 countries worldwide, providing opportunities for employees to work on global projects and collaborate with colleagues from diverse cultural backgrounds. Career Development: NTT Data invests in employee training and development, providing opportunities for advancement and career growth. The company also encourages its employees to pursue professional certifications and offers resources and support to help them do so. Competitive Compensation: NTT Data offers competitive compensation packages and benefits to its employees, including healthcare, retirement, and other perks. Commitment to Diversity and Inclusion: NTT Data is committed to promoting diversity and inclusion in its workforce and providing a supportive and inclusive work environment for all employees. Focus on Innovation: NTT Data is constantly exploring new technologies and approaches to solve complex business challenges. Working for NTT Data provides an opportunity to work on cutting-edge projects and contribute to innovative solutions. Overall, working for NTT Data can be a rewarding experience for those looking to work in the IT industry, with opportunities for career growth, global collaboration, and exposure to new technologies and approaches.
cons: While there are several potential benefits to working for NTT Data, there are also some potential drawbacks to consider. These include: Workload: Depending on the specific role and project, employees at NTT Data may experience a high workload and long hours, which can lead to burnout and stress. Limited Flexibility: NTT Data has a hierarchical organizational structure that can limit employee autonomy and flexibility in decision-making and project management. Bureaucracy: As a large global organization, NTT Data can have complex bureaucratic processes and procedures, which can slow down decision-making and hinder innovation. Lack of Work-Life Balance: Some employees at NTT Data have reported a lack of work-life balance, particularly when working on time-sensitive or high-pressure projects. Limited Career Opportunities: While NTT Data does offer opportunities for career development, some employees may feel that there is limited upward mobility or that their career growth is constrained by the company's organizational structure. Overall, while NTT Data can offer many benefits to employees, it may not be the best fit for everyone. It's important to carefully consider the potential drawbacks and weigh them against the potential benefits when deciding whether to work for the company.

review_title: If it's a US govt contract, stay away
pros: Unfortunately, within this particular environment, only the Stars rewards program.
cons: NTT took over a US govt contract in 2020 for an oil and gas bureau that is part of DOI. After they took over, the portions of the contract they became responsible for quickly began to crumble. They promoted individuals to leadership who were good tech-wise and on the contract for many years, but not leaders. Ergo, projects were poorly managed and became very brittle. Some sub contractors working with NTT were were let go to compensate for the client not liking progress and thus not giving additional project requests to NTT - no additional billable hours. However, it was not presented to those people that way. Skilled team members saw this and began to leave, exacerbating the sub-par environment. An almost combative and disrespectful culture was allowed further reducing morale. Paired with unrealistic promises for 'code release' schedules folks were stretched to the breaking point. NTT is more concerned with slow back-filling of a vacant spot, increasing profitability while charging the client for hours the vacancy technically isn't submitting. The aforementioned promoted "leaders" are content to claim "no one wants to work" yet they spend time during normal working hours on personal needs while their group staff are indeed doing the work. Then said "leaders" will expect work to be done during their convenience - typically after normal hours. For non-disruptive, non-critical work.

pros: The benefits are good and the pay was reasonable.
cons: My entire group was abandoned without a word being said to us. We were a small practice supporting Lawson/Infor that was acquired when the Revere Group was purchased by NTT. Things went well at first. We had always been profitable and always had a steady backlog of work. Without notifying any of us, our salesman was pulled from the team. Suddenly, we weren't landing projects anymore. Eventually billable work dried up and people began leaving. Eventually, only a few of us were left and we were each laid off slowly. It feels horrible to be abandoned by your employer without so much as a word. Additionally, I was told I was being laid off because I was less than 50% billable for three straight months, when actually, I was over 80% billable for the first two months of the period. I brought this up to HR and they told me that it really doesn't matter. So why lie?+

review_title: How to make the easy difficult.
pros: It’s growing, that’s about the best bit.
cons:
IT; Appalling on boarding process. Nothing but fire fighting:
1. No mobile in the first 4 weeks (critical for customer IT access).
2. No laptop for the first week. All induction training taken on personal IT, including IT on boarding. 
3. Multiple accounts for various elements of the business. Has this major IT company not understood SSO?
4. Because of the multi varied accounts raising a ticket for faults is like driving to Uzbekistan, underwater! You’ll get wet and hot but you won’t get anywhere because nobody will do anything in IT. 
5. Poor IT impacts personal renumeration. If you don’t select within 5 days you’re locked in for a year. Massive impact on pension options etc. 

No help:
1. Sexism? My partner had no problems and she was fighting the help off. If your male you’re on your own. Massively different experience. Why? 
2. Can’t wait to throw you at their customers, even with all the issues around IT.
3. None existent mentoring for me. My partner had more mentors than she can shake a stick at. 
4. Expects you to project manage without basic project management tools such as Microsoft project.
5. No ability to raise risks and issues on Jira even though your expected to be a super user. 
6. Jira locked down to the point that there is no Gant chart; no problem though as nobody puts any time boxes around their output.

To top it off, I can’t talk to anyone in my parent organisation as I again can’t access their IT.

Job Stability. 
Good Recruitment Incentives.

Works hour flexibility.

cons:
In context to Indian Offices:
I would have rated 5 star but when it comes to Talent Acquisition, the salary is low, it should be increased by at least 40% among all levels (there are incentives but salary is salary). 
Max standard yearly appraisal is 5%, which is pretty low. The lowest should be 10% and then it can be further increased based upon performance. To match inflation 10% is least expected by any employee.
We have good Leave Policies but managers can push team members to avail leave (in context to Indian Offices). As lot discussion are going world wide for mental, taking regular leave from work is really important.

review_title: Consultant for 3 years at NTT Data Services
pros: I have overall enjoyed my experience at NTT. I began before covid changed my workplace to remote and my favorite part of the company has always been my coworkers. Everyone, including superiors (within reason) are extremely approachable and available. NTT is also a growth oriented company and works hard to ensure employees are gaining experience and have a direction while striving to expand itself.
cons: NTT has a bit of an identity crisis on where it fits in the market. The mindset of company leaders is to push and close the gap between NTT and larger consulting firms which has caused the loss of some of the personality NTT had as a smaller consulting arm of a global company. There is some struggle with mobility among projects and managers willingness to allow you to take new roles if it means they lose a resource on their current project.

Their onboarding process is convoluted and overcomplicated that needlessly duplicates efforts, further extending the amount of time you're unable to perform your job. I kept being told that projects/clients were coming but they never did (something would always fall through). It felt like I was wasting my time and that management had no idea why they even hired me in the first place. The benefits were expensive and not great.

pros: They had the infrastructure to adapt to the pandemic and allow work from home for positions that can be done at home. Other than that, the pros were limited.
cons: Based on my own personal experience, the pay is low in comparison to the current market value and health benefits were more expensive. They withhold vacation payout despite not communicating that upon hire. I recommend researching your state employment laws and don't allow them to get over. They also want to give more work with no additional pay and seem to have a tough time keeping clients happy/ holding on to contracts which makes emoyment less stable. Payroll also appears to be disorganized with frequent occurences of late or innacurate pay. It is tough to reach someone in the company to resolve these issues. Trying to get IT support or contact with HR or payroll is near impossible and often times, they have a tough time communicating in English.

review_title: I would look elsewhere, If I were you
pros:
Reasonable Salary
Some good employees
Team mentality
cons:
- Poor training options - no certifications unless you do it in your own time, unless it's SAFe taught by other employees (minimal cost)
- Terrible projects - too many bodyshop roles with zero growth opportunities, the projects NTT win are the projects the big firms didn't want. Or its pure advisory work handing over to another firm to deliver
- Project Staffing - NTT will overpromise on skills available then struggle to mobilise a team, often having to dip into the contractor market which is ridiculous for a consulting firm whose main asset is its resources.
- "Magic Time" - having to do additional work to support your practice alongside your project work. Being told to make time to create assets which feel like doing work for the sake of it.
- Shocking tools - Original SAP, the intranet is a basic and poorly designed site. The firm doesn't even get trial environments or licences for certain softwares.
- No sales teams - When you are on the bench, you are thrown into bids that may not have anything to do with your skillset, because NTT wont hire a dedicated sales team.
- Poor benefits - really poor options
- Limited growth opportunities - there are multiple consultant levels, when at another firm you would have been a manager.

review_title: They Will Screw You Over If You Leave
pros: The People and that's literally it - a few individuals are the ones who kept me there longer than I would've initially stayed
cons:
Everything else including lines of communication, respectfulness, career trajectory, job opportunities, etc.

I had been experiencing frustration for quite a while but stayed because of all the positive people I had met. I left Big 4 because of the endless opportunities and engaging work I was promised here. I specifically said I did not want to do PM/PMO work because I felt my last firm siloed me into that and I was trying to get out of that and try new things. It was confirmed I would be able to do that here. Well within my first month of joining, I was told they had no projects in my vertical and was placed in a PMO Role on a client not even in my industry. During this time I continuously reached out and networked with people in my practice, engaged myself in various internal initiatives, and helped lead a pro bono volunteer project as well. The timing just did not match and so when a recruiter reached out to me on LinkedIn, I had an initial phone call and things progressed from there. Keep in mind this entire time my practice still had no active engagements. 

Moving forward, I put in my notice and calculated my two weeks and put that date in my official letter of resignation. It was confirmed by my manager. Immediately after giving notice, the practice lead called me and was very accusatory and aggressive on the phone call. I was accused of not being engaged enough, being fed misinformation, and poked about where I was going next and who told me what (which felt like I was being asked to throw people under the bus). It was a very uncomfortable phone call and I was made to feel guilty for leaving. Fast forward 2 days and I receive a call from my manager indicating that since I am not staffed on a project they will be letting me go today with pay and benefits ending today as well. This leaves me over a week without pay and benefits which is highly inconvenient as well as just bad practice in my personal opinion. I had just paid my insurance premium on the last paycheck too and so thought I would have coverage until at least the end of the month...NOPE. And thanks for letting me know all this at 12 pm on my last day that I had ZERO say in. To preach that you care about your people and then turn around and do that after my last day of employment was previously agreed upon is pretty awful. I was completely blindsided and would've waited to put in my notice until later if I had known I would have a major lapse in coverage. It was extremely disappointing and upsetting to be treated this way and I did not want to burn any bridges but they have successfully done that themselves.
